|Title=Knowing when to refer a patient for a tobaccology consultation
|Description=Tobacology: First recourse, 5A method (ask, assess, advise, assist and arrange)
|Rubric=Management
|Contributors=
|Order=32}}
Every medical consultation should be an opportunity to advise patients to stop smoking.

The professional advises each smoker to stop smoking and discusses the help and support available to help them do so.

ALL healthcare professionals MUST suggest stopping smoking (using the 5A technique) at EVERY consultation:

* ask if the person smokes (''Ask'')
* assess their smoking habits
* advise each smoker to stop smoking (''Advise'')
* explain the range of help and support available to help them achieve this ('''Assist'')
* offer written information to support this advice (''Arrange'')

This minimum advice helps to increase the weaning rate.

Don't hesitate to refer patients to the <nowiki>http://www.tabac-info-service.fr</nowiki> websites and the 3989 free telephone line, which offer personalised support (coaching).

question.question: When should a healthcare professional suggest stopping smoking to a patient during a consultation?
question.option_a: Only if the patient explicitly asks about smoking cessation.
question.option_b: After assessing the patient's smoking habits and willingness to quit.
question.option_c: When the patient presents with smoking-related health issues.
question.option_d: During every consultation, regardless of the patient's smoking status.
